peopleAlsoAsk.question: How do you date old screws?
peopleAlsoAsk.snippet: Examine the furniture screws carefully. Furniture screws were not fully machine-made until 1848. So, if you come across antique furniture hardware with screws that have fully rounded shafts, pointy ends, and flawlessly polished heads with matching cuts, it is most likely from the mid-nineteenth century or later.
peopleAlsoAsk.title: Tips on How to Date Antique Furniture Hardware - Riwick

peopleAlsoAsk.question: How to identify antique screws on wood?
peopleAlsoAsk.snippet: Look at rust from oxidation. It should be reddish in color like you would expect to see on steel. New screws and mails are shiny with a zinc coat to prevent rust. The wood around an old uncoated nail or screw would be oxidized black.
peopleAlsoAsk.title: Antique Furniture Screws — AntqRestoration.com™

peopleAlsoAsk.question: What did screws look like in the 1800s?
peopleAlsoAsk.snippet:
Many of these screws were flat bottomed, until it was realized that a pointed end worked better as a fastener. Screws made from about 1812 through the mid-1800s were partially machine made, giving the threading a more even appearance.
Aug 23, 2017
peopleAlsoAsk.title: The Antiques Addict | The Georgetowner

peopleAlsoAsk.question: What is the 100 year rule for antiques?
peopleAlsoAsk.snippet: The customary definition of antique requires that an item should be at least 100 years old and in original condition. (Motor vehicles are an exception to this rule, with some definitions requiring an automobile to be as little as 25 years old to qualify as an antique.)
